prompt.p: A 29-year-old woman complains of anterior triangle tender swelling. She is recovering from a recent viral chest infection. She feels lethargic, her pulse is 90 beats/min and her temperature is 37.8Â°C. On examination, she has an enlarged tender thyroid gland.
What is the most appropriate management?

modalFeedback.p: Option A (Aspirin) is Correct. This patient has a De Quervain's thyroiditis due to a self-limiting upper respiratory tract infection. Mild causes can be treated with a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug. A severe case may require prednisolone in the short term.
Option B (Levothyroxine) is Incorrect. This is used to treat hypothyroidism. The patient has a pulse that is not bradycardic, which is a feature of hypothyroidism.
Option C (Propranolol) is Incorrect. This is used in hyperthyroidism and thyroid crisis. Such a patient would be tachycardic, i.e. have a pulse rate >100 beats/min.
Option D (Propylthiouracil) is Incorrect. This is used to treat hyperthyroidism. It decreases thyroxine. Such a patient would be tachycardic, i.e. have a pulse rate >100 beats/min.
Option E (Radioiodine) is Incorrect. Iodine 131 is used to treat thyrotoxicosis and thyroid carcinoma. Its use may cause thyroiditis.
